title: Help! My therapist is secretly using ChatGPT
author: MIT Technology Review - AI
essence: - What’s new: Some therapists are using ChatGPT to process patient confessions, despite professional guidelines (e.g., American Counseling Association) advising against AI in therapy. Nevada and Illinois recently banned AI in therapeutic decision-making. - Why it matters: Patients may unknowingly  sensitive data with AI, risking privacy breaches or misdiagnoses.
reactions: ) Possible Impact: If therapists secretly use ChatGPT for patient notes, it could lead to misdiagnoses or breaches of confidentiality, as AI lacks clinical training and ethical safeguards.
) Skeptic Check: OpenAI’s Sam Altman calling ChatGPT a "good" therapy tool is misleading, as the article notes AI lacks the confrontational, growth-oriented elements of real therapy.
) Concrete Fact: Nevada and Illinois have already passed laws banning AI in therapeutic decision-making, signaling growing regulatory scrutiny (MIT Tech Review).

title: AI is changing the grid. Could it help more than it harms?
author: MIT Technology Review - AI
essence: - What's new: AI is accelerating grid forecasting and planning (e.g., Midcontinent ISO’s Pearl Street partnership) but faces skepticism over overhyped claims. - Why it matters: Grid operators, utilities, and communities are affected—AI could optimize efficiency but risks exacerbating demand spikes (e.g., data centers’ 80% energy surge from 2020–2025). - Evidence/caveats: Data centers’ demand may double by 2030 (945 TWh, Japan’s annual use), but AI’s benefits (e.g., faster interconnection studies) remain unproven at scale.
reactions: ) Possible Impact: AI-driven forecasting tools, like those used by grid operators, could reduce electricity waste by optimizing supply-demand matching, potentially shaving off emissions (per Kyri Baker, University of Colorado Boulder).

) Skeptic Check: Critics like Panayiotis Moutis (CUNY) argue AI’s grid benefits haven’t kept pace with its energy demands, noting data center electricity use is set to double by 2030, outstripping current AI efficiency gains.

) Concrete Fact: Google’s 2025 energy disclosure revealed a single AI prompt consumes ~0.3 watt-hours, with data centers already accounting for 80% higher electricity demand since 2020 (MIT Technology Review).

reactions: ) Possible Impact: If AI adoption scales to projections (e.g., 22% of US household electricity by 2028), data centers could trigger lasting energy infrastructure shifts, even if demand later plateaus.

) Skeptic Check: OpenAI’s 0.34 watt-hours per ChatGPT query lacks methodological details, and Google’s median figure omits high-energy tasks like long responses or video generation, making comparisons unreliable.
) Concrete Fact: Microsoft’s emissions surged 23% since 2020 due to AI, despite its 2030 carbon-negative pledge, highlighting the tension between AI growth and sustainability goals.
